newsitem.title: USA: U.S. money managers more defensive on US debt-MCM.
newsitem.headline: U.S. money managers more defensive on US debt-MCM.

text.p: U.S. fixed-income managers continued to cut the durations of their U.S. debt portfolios over the past week, according to an MCM MoneyWatch Inc survey.
"Weighted durations fell ... but cash positions dipped," according to MCM first vice president and senior economist Astrid Adolfson. "The dip may reflect a rise in outflows," she said.
In the week ended April 14, the survey showed durations as a percentage of benchmark fell to 106.3 percent from 106.9 percent the week before.
A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market.
A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 46 percent of total assets in the survey said they would "buy," compared with 40 percent the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" fell to 8.0 percent, down from 11 percent in the week ended April 7.
Forty-six percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market, down from 49 percent a week ago.
Cash as a percentage of assets fell to 3.36 percent, against 3.51 percent registered the previous week.

The survey showed 31 percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, up from 27 percent the previous week, while 10 percent underweighted it. The remaining 59 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 44 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 15 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 38 domestic participants who manage about $110 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM and usually is released on Tuesday.
